content: just played this one, it was very fun and satisfying, but I can understand why some people don't like it. i enjoyed this being so math-based, I think we need more clashes like this. it's crazy though, although it took me a while to come up with the math solution, i was able to figure it out because of when i liked to examine patterns with squared numbers 9 years ago!
IMHO, max N should either be lowered to allow scripting language to brute force (discussed under ChiefChippy2's thread), OR should be increased to make sure NO language can brute force it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a clean puzzle and can be solved in the time given if attention is given to reading the problem statement :)
well, I gave it a good attempted without looking at the solution and I couldn't accomplish it in 15 min.  I like the purity of this puzzle, but the solution evaded me.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Please lower the max N and edit your solution, as the exact same implementation in other common languages like python or ruby will time out more than half the time.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The author was very responsive and made a lot of small changes according to comments. It is now understandable, correct, can be easily solved and suitable for all game modes given.

While the constraints make it clear I think it's prudent to emphasize the non-negativeness in the statement. Suggestion:
"Given an integer N, find non-negatative integers A and B such that N^2 = A^2 - B^2. If multiple such solutions exist, find the one where A - B is minimal."

I tend to make it more math-y than it probably should be, so feel free to change it any way you feel like it. If you go my way then formula is missing from the goal and therefore Input and Output needs rephrasing. Most likely to simply "A non-negative integer N" and "A and B separated by space", respectively.

Since 0 is added to the mix, constraints need updating to allow that with B <= A.

Lastly, a TIOLI comment. I like your test case naming, small numbers written down, but for larger numbers, for tests the number suffices, i.e. "Test 15" to "15". Validators containing the word Validator in them is always a good idea.

I really like this problem now with a little bit of formatting, I'm happy to give it a go. Good job.

For C = 1 or 2, the answer for A is 0. So the constraints are not coherent.

I would open the constraints to:
0 <= C < 10000
0 <= A < B
I'm upvoting.  A nice and concise CoC puzzle.  I would have a stroke doing this in reverse

Nice problem. I would not like it in reverse mode however.
I was first perturbed by the naming order of the variables (I would have given n, find a and b such that n² = a²-b² and b-a is minimal but > 0.

How are you sure it is always possible?
Actually I solved the equation :
Set b=a+d, then the equation become c² = (a+d)²-a² = 2ad + d²
Note that the parity of d as to be the same as the parity of c, so d = 1 if c is odd else d = 2. Any d greater would not be minimal.
Then a = (c²-d²)/2d, which is always integer with the chosen d.

So the solution become simply:
c = int(input())
d = 2 if c%2 == 0 else 1
a = (c**2 - d**2)//(2*d)
b = a+d
print(b, a)
It's probably interesting only for shortest but there is a closed formula for this one. I like those a lot.
Edit: improved constraints. thanks @ChiefChippy2

Yep, I would like to see it in shortest mode too.
More time to think about the closed form :)

I am just concerned that brute force could be quicker to think about ^^'

Could we push c to up to 10000 ? :)
I removed Reverse game mode.  Both you and Flaaamort agreed it would be annoying.
That's interesting.  I would need to work out a new solution that handles values of zero.
Thanks!  I added your suggestions.

I understand your concern.  Initially, the max N was 100 and the reference solution was appropriate as a general solution.  The discussion among other reviewers pushed things to a more "thoughtful" puzzle that is designed for an analytical solution.  The reference solution is at the brink of what is possible without timing out.
It took me 20 minutes to find the solution, even knowing the general form of it.

I read through the rest of the comments but not referencing the code, I write up a solution that focus on searching for solutions by distance between a and b.

Here is my python solution.  I did not think of this on my own but instead had to read the comments and get suggestions

n = int(input())
ns = n*n

#  n^2 = a^2 - b^2
#  d = a-b
#  n*n = a^2 - d^2 + 2ad - a^2
#  n*n = 2ad - d^2

if n == 0:
    print("0 0")
else:
    for d in range(1,100):
        a = int((ns + d*d)/(2*d))
        b = a - d
        if a*a - b*b == ns:
            print(f"{a} {b}")
            break

I completely disagree with this rejection. First of all, nothing, absolutely nothing forces you to brute-force a problem. It is indeed a bad habit and should always be a last resort. Secondly, literally the most simply mathematical identity is the only thing you need to use to make this easy, but just a tad more complex, yet still trivial approach can yield a result in no time. Third, there is literally a closed formula for this one that works for everything but 0 (that you can hardcode) which means it is solvable in O(1) in any language that can handle 32-bit integers and the 4 basic arithmetic operations.

And lastly my personal opinion. Nothing makes me happier than a problem that doesn't work for Python. There are a 100 problems that are designed in a way that you only have to import some Python lib to call a function and not think. I guess the idea is that the sooner your brain dies, the better. It's a horrible habit and it's already showing in the profession how extereme disadvantage is when you think that's the way to do software development.

1 A solution should be more optimized than looping 150 million times. Yes, I know there's definitely better approaches, but op should implement it in their solution then, instead of leaving a solution that is inefficient. I also want the max N to be lowered because I'd suppose people would brute force if they don't know the formula, and even though that's a bad practice, it shouldn't be a 0% if following the author's approach. ( but again, coc is far from relatively good practice)
1b if there's a formula, then perhaps the author should use it in their solution or mention it in their statement. 
2 "Nothing makes me happier than a problem that doesn't work in Python". Are you trying to say a clash that is undoable for like half the community is good? Reminder that coc is not puzzles, so the difficulty should be moderate, and a lot of people use python. If anything importing a lib is actually better than implementing your own algorithm at times because 1 it is shorter ( and yes we are talking about speed and/or code size here ), 2 it probs will be more efficient than the algorithm you implement (or as efficient). I'm not saying its the way to do software development but coc isn't that at all, it's entertainment.

You make some good points.

I do want to clarify that 12/16 (75%) test cases pass easily with Python using the brute force solution (with slightly smaller range).
I was able to code a solution in python that easily finished in time and reliably.

Let me be clear on this one. There a guideline that a CoC should be solvable in less than 15 minutes. If you don't do anything but look at the test cases it's as simple as that to notice the difference between A and B is 1 or 2 based on parity. So the problem really boils down to basic pattern recognition that I would expect an average 12 year old to be capable of.

There are at least 3 super easy mathematical approaches to use to solve this one. Any of those should be more than feasible in way less than 10 minutes. 

Having just a tad optimized solution that involves no math at all just trial and error and knowing the super basics of programming is viable to solve this. Which proves the point that you tried to validate a problem without even getting a slight thought about it.

The author should NEVER in any case provide the optimal solution/shortest solution to the problem because that can and will be used by cheaters. I personally asked the author to revert his optimal solution. If you don't know how to cheat it's fine, unfortunately there is a way and I've seen it in actual CoC and that's why I encourage verbose sub-optimal solutions.

And lastly. What you say is perfectly valid for languages like Java, C# and others where libraries are written by language experts and maintained by them, too. For Python and Javascript it's an unimaginable pain. The amount of times I've seen customer impacting failures because of some untested, unmaintained dependency was pulled in, and actual code was relying on it is insanely high. Unless it's numpy and matplotlib and alike which are actually good it's a huge red flag. And those are the 0.1% of available libraries. If for anyone it's entertaining to come and copy 3 lines of code with some random magic library that they don't understand at all, I will have bad news no matter which career path they take.

And to finish off with a personal opinion. If you come to CodinGame and manage to not learn anything and not develop your skills at all, something went horribly wrong there.

coc is not really going to teach you good practice i think... can't say I didn't learn anything but if i actually start doing what i do in coc in other places.... let's just say it will go bad.
and again, the solution should at least in my opinion be more optimized. 
If you want to argue people will cheat in CoC : fine, but they can just copy and paste the solution code, change variable names and pass...i dont see how a worse solution can prevent one from doing that...

Also, it's not that I didn't solve it, it's that I actually checked to see if the author's solution is even remotely possible in other languages... the results are known already. Of course this doesn't mean python can't solve this...not at all! If someone wants to check the solution afterwards the clash because they had no idea how to solve it, they will want to recode it in their language, and guess what, they'll get timeouts and be like "bruh ok this isn't solvable my language".

I also said to lower max N because naive brute forcing attempts (like the current one of the author) shouldn't be timing out that much.

I agree with what you said about libraries, but in the particular case of coc, importing something can be shorter or faster (ie in ruby ill import prime for all the prime related thing instead of rewriting the algorithm).

aight as you see, someone else approved it, so my rejection was not useful. congrats on getting a clash approved.
Technically this is an equation not a formula but I don't care about that, it is perfectly fine like this.
Good point, though.  Easily fixed :D
I've added two end of sentence periods in the Goal section and approved it. Good job.
I renamed the variables per your original comment.  Also the test cases go up to 10000 now :D

It's easy to add more test cases.  Originally I wasn't thinking of Pythagorean formula at all (left-side squared).  As the title suggests I was interested in N = A^2 - B^2 (with your variable names).  I'm not sure why I restricted the solution space to N^2.  I think I just wanted to add a bit of spice.  It ended up making it very very similar to right-triangle formula so that was a bust.

Using N=A^2-B2, some values of N do not have an answer.
For example N=6. Actually all N = 4k+2 do not have an answer, all others have at least one.
Luckily, squares can only be in the form 4k+0 or 4k+1.
I stole your direct solution code.  Thanks!
Haha, no problem ;)

With that said: can you revert back to the old verbose solution with all the loops and stuff. These problems are more than searchable in the shortest mode and your current solution gives a huge advantage for cheaters. It is a good solution for shortest that can be sanitized but we shouldn't try to support that use-case.
Can you explain the bit about cheaters?  I don't really get it.

In that case I would rather not give away tips to anyone reading this. There is a way to cheat which is unusable for shortest, unless you give away a good code for shortest mode. That's why even the golf specific problems usually come with very verbose and inefficient solutions.

Just to clarify, I didn't assume in any way that you would cheat. This is a protection against others reading it in the future.
